response_metadata.response_text:
{
"overview": "The purpose of this measure is to increase the cigarette tax beginning July 1, 2025, and allocate the increase in the cigarette tax amount to be deposited into the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). Your Committee on Higher Education has amended this measure by changing the cigarette tax amount and dispositions of the cigarette tax revenue to unspecified amounts (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). The committee believes that an increase in the cigarette tax will restore funding for the University of Hawaii Cancer Center and expand its capacity to conduct groundbreaking research and deliver patient care (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt).",
"appropriations": "Your Committee respectfully requests your Committee on Finance to consider establishing a tax rate of 18.00 cents for each cigarette or little cigar sold on and after July 1, 2025 (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). It also requests consideration for depositing 4.0 cents per cigarette to the credit of the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund, and 1.125 cents per cigarette, but no more than $7,400,000.00 (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt) in a fiscal year, to the Trauma System Special Fund (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). Additionally, it requests depositing 1.25 cents per cigarette, but no more than $8,800,000.00 (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt) in a fiscal year, to the Community Health Centers Special Fund, and 1.25 cents per cigarette, but no more than $8,800,000.00 (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt) in a fiscal year, to the Emergency Medical Services Special Fund (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt).",
"assumptions_and_methodology": "Testimony estimates that a $1.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) per pack cigarette tax increase in Hawaiʻi will generate $10.84 million (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) in new revenue in its first year (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). This increase is projected to prevent 500 kids in Hawai’i from becoming smokers, prompt 2,000 smokers to quit, and prevent 500 smoking-caused deaths (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). Another projection estimates an increase of $1.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) per pack will generate $11.46 million (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) per annum (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt).",
"agency_impact": "",
"economic_impact": "Projected public health benefits from a cigarette tax rate increase include 5-year health care cost savings from fewer smoking-caused lung cancer cases of $360,000.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt), and 5-year health care cost savings from fewer smoking-affected pregnancies and births of $190,000.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). Further savings include 5-year health care cost savings from fewer smoking-caused heart attacks & strokes of $220,000.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt), with long-term health care cost savings from adult & youth smoking declines projected at $31.80 million (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt).",
"policy_impact": "Your Committee has amended this measure by changing the cigarette tax amount and dispositions of the cigarette tax revenue to unspecified amounts (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). The Committee on Higher Education recommends that the measure be referred to the Committee on Finance in the form of H.B. No. 441, H.D. 2 (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). This action defers the final policy decision on specific tax rates and allocations to the Committee on Finance.",
"revenue_sources": "The dispositions for FY24 show that the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund received $8,606,752.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt), the Emergency Medical Services Special Fund received $4,841,298.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt), and both the Community Health Centers Special Fund and Trauma System Special Fund each received $5,379,220.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). The General Fund received the remainder of approximately $58,789,339 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt).",
"six_year_fiscal_implications": "Projections for a cigarette tax rate increase include a 5-year reduction in the number of smoking-affected pregnancies and births of 80 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). Over five years, projected health care cost savings from fewer smoking-caused lung cancer cases amount to $360,000.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). Additional savings include $190,000.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) from fewer smoking-affected pregnancies and births, and $220,000.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) from fewer smoking-caused heart attacks and strokes over the same period (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). The projected 5-year Medicaid program savings for the state is $990,000.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). Testimony projects that a $1.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) per pack increase would generate new annual revenue of $10.84 million (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt), while another estimate suggests it would generate $11.46 million (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) annually (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt).",
"operating_revenue_impact": "According to testimony, a $1.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) per pack cigarette tax increase in Hawaiʻi is projected to generate $10.84 million (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) in new annual revenue (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). Another estimate projects that an increase of $1.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) per pack will generate $11.46 million (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) per annum (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). These projections indicate a potential increase in state operating revenue if a tax increase is enacted.",
"capital_expenditure_impact": "Testimony states that funding from the cigarette tax has been instrumental since its inception in 2006, enabling the construction of the UH Cancer Center building (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). The amended bill specifies that money deposited to the credit of the Hawaii cancer research special fund is for research and operating expenses and for capital expenditures (HB441_HD2_.HTM.txt). This indicates a continued potential for capital expenditures from this fund.",
"fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The measure's effective date is July 1, 3000 (HB441_HD2_.HTM.txt), deferring long-term fiscal implications. The Committee has amended the measure by changing the cigarette tax amount and dispositions of the cigarette tax revenue to unspecified amounts (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). This creates further uncertainty regarding the long-term fiscal impact until specific rates are established.",
"updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "The Committee on Higher Education amended the measure, changing the cigarette tax amount and revenue dispositions to unspecified amounts and referring it to the Committee on Finance (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). The committee report includes specific recommendations for the Finance Committee to consider, including setting caps of $7,400,000.00 (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt) and $8,800,000.00 (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt) for certain special funds. New testimony provides a more detailed breakdown of FY24 revenues for the special funds and specific five-year projections for health care cost savings resulting from a tax increase."
}

"overview": "The purpose of this measure is to increase the cigarette tax beginning July 1, 2025, and allocate the increase in the cigarette tax amount to be deposited into the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). Your Committee on Higher Education has amended this measure by changing the cigarette tax amount and dispositions of the cigarette tax revenue to unspecified amounts (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). The committee believes that an increase in the cigarette tax will restore funding for the University of Hawaii Cancer Center and expand its capacity to conduct groundbreaking research and deliver patient care (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt).",
"appropriations": "Your Committee respectfully requests your Committee on Finance to consider establishing a tax rate of 18.00 cents for each cigarette or little cigar sold on and after July 1, 2025 (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). It also requests consideration for depositing 4.0 cents per cigarette to the credit of the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund, and 1.125 cents per cigarette, but no more than $7,400,000.00 (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt) in a fiscal year, to the Trauma System Special Fund (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). Additionally, it requests depositing 1.25 cents per cigarette, but no more than $8,800,000.00 (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt) in a fiscal year, to the Community Health Centers Special Fund, and 1.25 cents per cigarette, but no more than $8,800,000.00 (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt) in a fiscal year, to the Emergency Medical Services Special Fund (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt).",
"assumptions_and_methodology": "Testimony estimates that a $1.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) per pack cigarette tax increase in Hawaiʻi will generate $10.84 million (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) in new revenue in its first year (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). This increase is projected to prevent 500 kids in Hawai’i from becoming smokers, prompt 2,000 smokers to quit, and prevent 500 smoking-caused deaths (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). Another projection estimates an increase of $1.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) per pack will generate $11.46 million (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) per annum (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt).",
"agency_impact": "",
"economic_impact": "Projected public health benefits from a cigarette tax rate increase include 5-year health care cost savings from fewer smoking-caused lung cancer cases of $360,000.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt), and 5-year health care cost savings from fewer smoking-affected pregnancies and births of $190,000.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). Further savings include 5-year health care cost savings from fewer smoking-caused heart attacks & strokes of $220,000.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt), with long-term health care cost savings from adult & youth smoking declines projected at $31.80 million (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt).",
"policy_impact": "Your Committee has amended this measure by changing the cigarette tax amount and dispositions of the cigarette tax revenue to unspecified amounts (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). The Committee on Higher Education recommends that the measure be referred to the Committee on Finance in the form of H.B. No. 441, H.D. 2 (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). This action defers the final policy decision on specific tax rates and allocations to the Committee on Finance.",
"revenue_sources": "The dispositions for FY24 show that the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund received $8,606,752.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt), the Emergency Medical Services Special Fund received $4,841,298.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt), and both the Community Health Centers Special Fund and Trauma System Special Fund each received $5,379,220.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). The General Fund received the remainder of approximately $58,789,339 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt).",
"six_year_fiscal_implications": "Projections for a cigarette tax rate increase include a 5-year reduction in the number of smoking-affected pregnancies and births of 80 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). Over five years, projected health care cost savings from fewer smoking-caused lung cancer cases amount to $360,000.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). Additional savings include $190,000.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) from fewer smoking-affected pregnancies and births, and $220,000.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) from fewer smoking-caused heart attacks and strokes over the same period (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). The projected 5-year Medicaid program savings for the state is $990,000.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). Testimony projects that a $1.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) per pack increase would generate new annual revenue of $10.84 million (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt), while another estimate suggests it would generate $11.46 million (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) annually (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt).",
"operating_revenue_impact": "According to testimony, a $1.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) per pack cigarette tax increase in Hawaiʻi is projected to generate $10.84 million (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) in new annual revenue (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). Another estimate projects that an increase of $1.00 (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) per pack will generate $11.46 million (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt) per annum (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). These projections indicate a potential increase in state operating revenue if a tax increase is enacted.",
"capital_expenditure_impact": "Testimony states that funding from the cigarette tax has been instrumental since its inception in 2006, enabling the construction of the UH Cancer Center building (HB441_HD1_TESTIMONY_HED_02-07-25_.PDF.txt). The amended bill specifies that money deposited to the credit of the Hawaii cancer research special fund is for research and operating expenses and for capital expenditures (HB441_HD2_.HTM.txt). This indicates a continued potential for capital expenditures from this fund.",
"fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The measure's effective date is July 1, 3000 (HB441_HD2_.HTM.txt), deferring long-term fiscal implications. The Committee has amended the measure by changing the cigarette tax amount and dispositions of the cigarette tax revenue to unspecified amounts (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). This creates further uncertainty regarding the long-term fiscal impact until specific rates are established.",
"updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "The Committee on Higher Education amended the measure, changing the cigarette tax amount and revenue dispositions to unspecified amounts and referring it to the Committee on Finance (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt). The committee report includes specific recommendations for the Finance Committee to consider, including setting caps of $7,400,000.00 (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt) and $8,800,000.00 (HB441_HD2_HSCR470_.PDF.txt) for certain special funds. New testimony provides a more detailed breakdown of FY24 revenues for the special funds and specific five-year projections for health care cost savings resulting from a tax increase."
}

chunk_details.chunk_text: TESTIMONY OF THE DEPARTMENT OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL KA ‘OIHANA O KA LOIO KUHINA THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 ON THE FOLLOWING MEASURE: H.B. NO. 441, H.D. 1, RELATING TO CIGARETTE TAXES. BEFORE THE: HOUSE COMMITTEE ON HIGHER EDUCATION DATE: Friday, February 7, 2025 TIME: 2:00 p.m. LOCATION: University of Hawaii at

7, 2025 TIME: 2:00 p.m. LOCATION: University of Hawaii at Manoa, Bachman Hall Board of Regents Conference Room 106 2444 Dole Street Honolulu, Hawaii 96822 TESTIFIER(S): Anne E. Lopez, Attorney General, or Richard W. Stacey, Deputy Attorney General Chair Garrett and Members of the Committee: The Department of the Attorney

and Members of the Committee: The Department of the Attorney General (Department) supports this bill and offers the following comments. The purpose of this bill is to increase the tax rate on each cigarette or little cigar sold from 16.00 cents to 18.00 cents. Additionally, the bill amends the disposition

cents to 18.00 cents. Additionally, the bill amends the disposition of revenues collected at the amended rate by increasing the cigarette tax amount allocated to the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund from 2.0 cents to 4.0 cents per cigarette. Cigarette tax stamp revenues have plummeted, from over $116 million in

tax stamp revenues have plummeted, from over $116 million in fiscal year 2015-2016 to just over $70 million in fiscal year 2023-2024. This decline has affected the funding for the University of Hawaii Cancer Center, community health centers, trauma centers, and emergency medical services. Similarly, the Department’s Tobacco Enforcement Special

and emergency medical services. Similarly, the Department’s Tobacco Enforcement Special Fund (Fund) has experienced a revenue decline due to reduced cigarettes sales. The Fund receives revenue from the cigarette tax stamp fee, which is directly tied to the cost of the cigarette tax stamp (see section 245-26, Hawaii Revised Statutes

the cigarette tax stamp (see section 245-26, Hawaii Revised Statutes (HRS)). The revenue deposited into the Fund has dropped from $1.74 million in fiscal year 2015-2016 to Testimony of the Department of the Attorney General Thirty-Third Legislature, 2025 Page 2 of 2 $1.03 million in 2023-2024. To ensure continued diligent

of 2 $1.03 million in 2023-2024. To ensure continued diligent enforcement of the Master Settlement Agreement (MSA), the Department needs to recuperate funding to the Fund. In 1998, Hawaii and 45 other states signed the MSA with the four largest U.S. tobacco manufacturers to settle smoking-related claims. Under the MSA,

U.S. tobacco manufacturers to settle smoking-related claims. Under the MSA, these manufacturers provide annual payments to the signing states, including Hawaii. To maintain these payments, states must diligently enforce the requirements of the "model statute," which Hawaii enacted as the Tobacco Liability Act, chapter 675, HRS. The Legislature established the

Tobacco Liability Act, chapter 675, HRS. The Legislature established the Fund in 2001 for the Department to administer, monitor, and enforce the MSA, the cigarette tax stamp program, and any other related statutes or programs (see section 28-15(a), HRS). If enforcement is deemed insufficient, tobacco manufacturers may challenge the payment,

enforcement is deemed insufficient, tobacco manufacturers may challenge the payment, potentially leading to arbitration and significant financial losses to Hawaii. Hawaii received over $36.4 million in MSA payments for fiscal year 2023-2024. Recent arbitration decisions found Washington, Missouri, and New Mexico non-diligent, jeopardizing their annual MSA payments. These decisions highlight

Mexico non-diligent, jeopardizing their annual MSA payments. These decisions highlight a critical need for stable funding for the Department to maintain and further its diligent enforcement efforts and reduce the risk of losing MSA revenue. The Department recognizes that continued reliance on declining cigarette tax revenue is unsustainable. Therefore, the

reliance on declining cigarette tax revenue is unsustainable. Therefore, the Department asks that the Committee also consider House Bill No. 1085. House Bill No. 1085 similarly raises the cigarette tax rate; however, this bill aims to move away from relying on cigarette taxes and expands the tax revenue base to

on cigarette taxes and expands the tax revenue base to include all revenue collected under chapter 245, HRS, including the new tax revenue collected from e-cigarettes and e-liquids. The attached chart demonstrates the flow of the cigarette and tobacco tax and license money. We respectfully urge the Committee to pass

and license money. We respectfully urge the Committee to pass this bill or, alternatively, consider House Bill No. 1085 as a viable option. We also ask that this Committee change the defective effective date to the original effective date of July 1, 2025. For the implementation of a new tax

Nakamura Speaker, House of Representatives Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Madame: Your Committee on Higher Education, to which was referred H.B. No. 441, H.D. 1, entitled:

to which was referred H.B. No. 441, H.D. 1, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO CIGARETTE TAXES," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose of this measure is to increase the cigarette tax beginning July 1, 2025, and allocate the increase in the cigarette tax amount to

and allocate the increase in the cigarette tax amount to be deposited into the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Department of the Attorney General; Department of Health; University of Hawaii Cancer Center; Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition; Hina Mauka; Hawaii

Hawaii Cancer Center; Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition; Hina Mauka; Hawaii Medical Association; Hawai ʻ i Pacific Health; Waianae Coast Comprehensive Health Center; Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids; The Queen's Health Systems; Coalition for a Tobacco-Free Hawai ʻ i; American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network; Hawai ʻ i Health & Harm Reduction

Cancer Action Network; Hawai ʻ i Health & Harm Reduction Center; American Lung Association; Kobayashi Group; and numerous individuals. Your Committee received testimony in opposition to this measure from Japan Tobacco International U.S.A., Inc.; Hawaii Smokers Alliance; Marukin Market; BMA Mart; Cigar Association of America; Wawa Market; Kilani Market; and

Mart; Cigar Association of America; Wawa Market; Kilani Market; and seven individuals. Your Committee received comments on this measure from the Department of Taxation; Tax Foundation of Hawaii; and Tax Foundation. Your Committee finds that funding from the cigarette tax has been instrumental since the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund's

has been instrumental since the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund's inception in 2006, enabling the construction of the University of Hawaii Cancer Center building and the launching of strategic initiatives to combat cancer. However, due to the success of smoking cessation efforts, this allocation has declined, indicating both progress in

cessation efforts, this allocation has declined, indicating both progress in public health and a concerning decrease in resources for the initiatives that have fueled this advancement. Your Committee believes that an increase in the cigarette tax will restore funding for the University of Hawaii Cancer Center and expand its capacity

the University of Hawaii Cancer Center and expand its capacity to conduct groundbreaking research and deliver patient care to save more lives across the State. Your Committee has amended this measure by: (1) Changing the cigarette tax amount and dispositions of the cigarette tax revenue to unspecified amounts ; and

of the cigarette tax revenue to unspecified amounts ; and (2) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity, consistency, and style. Your Committee respectfully requests your Committee on Finance, should it deliberate on this measure, to consider: (1) Establishing a tax rate of 18.00 cents for each cigarette

Establishing a tax rate of 18.00 cents for each cigarette or little cigar sold, used, or possessed by a wholesaler or dealer on and after July 1, 2025; and (2) After June 30, 2025, depositing the following amounts from the cigarette tax revenue into the appropriate special funds: (A) 4.0

cigarette tax revenue into the appropriate special funds: (A) 4.0 cents per cigarette to be deposited to the credit of the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund; (B) 1.125 cents per cigarette, but no more than $7,400,000 in a fiscal year, to be deposited to the credit of the Trauma System

to be deposited to the credit of the Trauma System Special Fund; (C) 1.25 cents per cigarette, but no more than $8,800,000 in a fiscal year, to be deposited to the credit of the Community Health Centers Special Fund; and (D) 1.25 cents per cigarette, but no more than $8,800,000

(D) 1.25 cents per cigarette, but no more than $8,800,000 in a fiscal year, to be deposited to the credit of the Emergency Medical Services Special Fund. As affirmed by the record of votes of the members of your Committee on Higher Education that is attached to this report, your

on Higher Education that is attached to this report, your Committee is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B. No. 441, H.D. 1, as amended herein, and recommends that it be referred to your Committee on Finance in the form attached hereto as H.B. No. 441, H.D. 2.

bill amends the disposition of revenues collected at the amended rate by increasing the cigarette tax amount allocated to the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund from 2.0 cents to 4.0 cents per cigarette. Cigarette tax stamp revenues have plummeted, from over $116 million in fiscal year 2015-2016 to just over $70 million in fiscal year 2023-2024. This decline has affected the funding for the University of Hawaii Cancer Center, community health centers, trauma centers, and emergency medical services. Similarly, the Department’s Tobacco Enforcement Special Fund (Fund) has experienced a revenue decline due to reduced cigarettes sales. The Fund receives revenue from

Fund (Fund) has experienced a revenue decline due to reduced cigarettes sales. The Fund receives revenue from the cigarette tax stamp fee, which is directly tied to the cost of the cigarette tax stamp (see section 245-26, Hawaii Revised Statutes (HRS)). The revenue deposited into the Fund has dropped from $1.74 million in fiscal year 2015-2016 to Testimony of the Department of the Attorney General Thirty-Third Legislature, 2025 Page 2 of 2 $1.03 million in 2023-2024. To ensure continued diligent enforcement of the Master Settlement Agreement (MSA), the Department needs to recuperate funding to the Fund. In 1998, Hawaii and 45

which is directly tied to the cost of the cigarette tax stamp (see section 245-26, Hawaii Revised Statutes (HRS)). The revenue deposited into the Fund has dropped from $1.74 million in fiscal year 2015-2016 to Testimony of the Department of the Attorney General Thirty-Third Legislature, 2025 Page 2 of 2 $1.03 million in 2023-2024. To ensure continued diligent enforcement of the Master Settlement Agreement (MSA), the Department needs to recuperate funding to the Fund. In 1998, Hawaii and 45 other states signed the MSA with the four largest U.S. tobacco manufacturers to settle smoking-related claims. Under the MSA, these manufacturers provide

for the Department to administer, monitor, and enforce the MSA, the cigarette tax stamp program, and any other related statutes or programs (see section 28-15(a), HRS). If enforcement is deemed insufficient, tobacco manufacturers may challenge the payment, potentially leading to arbitration and significant financial losses to Hawaii. Hawaii received over $36.4 million in MSA payments for fiscal year 2023-2024. Recent arbitration decisions found Washington, Missouri, and New Mexico non-diligent, jeopardizing their annual MSA payments. These decisions highlight a critical need for stable funding for the Department to maintain and further its diligent enforcement efforts and reduce the risk of losing MSA
